if statement

The if statement is a syntax that determines whether or not to execute part of a script based on a conditional judgment, such as "if ○○, then do ●●".
The syntax is as follows:

if(expression)
    statement or block
else
    statement or block
The first "statement or block" is executed when the result of evaluating the expression is true, and the second "statement or block" is executed when the evaluation result is false. The else part and what follows can be omitted if not needed.

Example:
    if(a==b)
        inform("a and b are the same");

    if(a<b)
    {
        var t;
        t=a; a=b; b=t; // swap a and b 
    }

    if(a==b)
        inform("a and b are the same");
    else
        inform("a and b are different");

Correspondence between if and else

The else follows the rule that it "corresponds to the nearest preceding if that is not already associated with an else".

For example,

    if(expr) // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
        else // ●
            statement;
    else // ★
        statement;
In this case, the ★ else corresponds to the ★ if, and the ● else corresponds to the ● if.
In a free-style language like TJS2, even if you write it with incorrect indentation like
    if(expr) // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
    else // ●
        statement;
it should be noted that the correspondence remains as described above.
If you want to clearly separate the associations, please use a method such as enclosing them in blocks:

    if(expr) { // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
    }
    else // ★
        statement;
